title: Assange denied bid to delay extradition trial
text:
He made a fist to supporters in public gallery, who included Australian journalist John Pilger and former London mayor Ken Livingston.

The glum 48-year-old seemed to struggle to remember his birth date at the beginning of the hearing.

But after rising to be addressed by District Judge Vanessa Baraister at the court's adjournment until November 18, Assange began to talk.

"I don't understand how it is equitable for this superpower that has had 10 years to work on this case and I can't access anything," he mumbled to the court.

"These people have unlimited resources.

"They are saying journalists and whistleblowers are enemies of the people ...They have an unfair advantage ... the interior of my life with my psychologist ... tried to steal my children's DNA.

"This is not equitable, what is happening here ... I've tried to speak to a US lawyer for five months, I still don't have a proper ... I can't think properly."

Earlier, defence barrister Mark Summers QC argued that his team needed at least three more months to gather evidence and that five days set for the trial in February would not be sufficient time to hear all the evidence.

Advertisement

Mr Summers pointed out that new evidence in the case, like Spanish contractors spying on Assange while he had asylum-seeker status in the Ecuadorian embassy, had only come to light since he had been arrested by British police six months ago.

"That's merely one tentacle of the octopus, but we hope the court can see the magnitude of the evidential task," Mr Summers told to court.

"To be blunt, we need more time."

Mr Summers also expressed concern about the conditions under which Assange was being held, including the fact that he has no access to a computer.

"It was only last week that we were able to pass him documents," the barrister said.

"Yesterday he received a box of documents dated July."

James Lewis, for the US government, said his side were strongly against any further delay in the case.

"The defence have had five-and-a-half months to prepare that evidence and we would resist a further extension," he said.

Advertisement

He also reiterated that there was no question about the legality of Assange's actions, accusing the Australian of knowingly risking the torture, death or arbitrary detention of US informants.

"It is not journalistic, actually it is criminal, both in the United States and the United Kingdom," Mr Lewis.

Judge Baraister refused to give the defence more time or extend the trial length and adjourned the case until November 18, with the full trial still set for February.

AAP ag

AAP
description: The Wikileaks founder appeared in court ahead of his extradition trial and accused the US government of attacking him and attempting to steal his children's DNA.
